name: frankframework
description: A Helm chart for running the Frank!Framework on Kubernetes
title: Chart
Frank!Framework Chart
description:
Running the Frank!Framework in Kubernetes is made easy with this Helm chart.
Multiple instances of the Frank!Framework can be deployed in the same Kubernetes cluster and managed from a single console (if enabled).

children.value:
Running the Frank!Framework in Kubernetes is made easy with this Helm chart.
Multiple instances of the Frank!Framework can be deployed in the same Kubernetes cluster and managed from a single console (if enabled).

Configurations can be copied over into a Container Image, or be mounted as a ConfigMap or Secret.
Just replace the image with the
parameters or mount the configurations with the

This chart can also be used as sub-chart for other charts, so other defaults can be provided and extra files can be added.
Take a look at the Frank2Example chart for a simple example.
must be installed to use the charts. Please refer to Helm's
Once Helm has been set up correctly, add the repo as follows:
If you had already added this repo earlier, run

to retrieve the latest versions of the packages.
You can then run
Configure the Frank!Framework by creating a

file.
Parameters can be found below, or in the
file, where additional documentation and examples are provided.
The Frank!Framework will start with different settings enabled, depending on what DTAP stage is configured. Like if the Ladybug should be disabled, or if authentication should be enabled.
For more information about DTAP stages read:

This chart defines the minimum required version of the Frank!Framework image.
To update to a newer version, you can set the
parameter to the desired version. Immutable tags are recommended.
This is also applicable for the Frank!Framework console, if enabled. The same tag can be used.
The usage of an authenticator is based on the

.
But it can be overridden with the
If the separate console is enabled, the console will

use the same authentication as the Frank!Framework.
And always needs to be configured.
Read more about configuring the authentication in the
A database is added for the Ladybug to make it somewhat persistent and to make the data accessible for all replicas.

The database is used for Ladybug reports and is not needed when Ladybug is disabled.
This is enabled by default, but can be disabled if you want to use an external database for Ladybug.
The database is not intended to be used with the Frank!Framework itself, that datasource should be configured with the
You can read more about it in the parameters section.
Common parameters for the Frank!Framework chart.
Can be used to override the default name for the chart.
String to partially override fullname template (will maintain the release name)
String to fully override fullname template
Information about how to use and configure the image can be found in the documentation:
The image is pulled from nexus.frankframework.org by default. The images located there will be kept for as long as possible.
If you want to use a specific nightly, you can use the images on docker.io:
Frank!Framework image tag (immutable tags are recommended) update this tag manually to upgrade the Frank!Framework version
Defaults to 'Always' if image tag is 'latest', else set to 'IfNotPresent'
Optionally specify an array of imagePullSecrets.
Secrets must be manually created in the namespace.

The application parameters are used to configure the Frank!Framework and how it will run.
For example, you can configure the DTAP stage and side of where the instance is running.
You can also configure the name of the instance. And what configurations to load.
The DTAP stage is used to enable and disable features in the Frank!Framework.
side of where the instance is running, and for sideSpecific properties
Set the name of the Frank! instance (default is the
Keep in mind that the name is used for the default datasource.
Set the configurations to load. Leave empty to use the default
Set YAML properties for configuring the Frank!Framework or configurations
Please read the section "Environment variables" for more information about the differance between
This section contains some parameters that are used to configure the deployment container of the Frank!Framework.
The command to run in the container
The arguments to pass to the command
The ports to expose in the container
The environment variables are used to configure the Frank!Framework.

is that the environment variables are set in the container and not in the YAML file.
Environment variables are immediately available in the container and can be used to configure the Frank!Framework, even before the YAML file has been loaded.
The YAML file is loaded by the Frank!Framework after it has been started.
This is an important differance because it means that some variables to configure the Frank!Framework can not be set in the YAML file.
It is possible to add environment variables with the
parameter and to add environment variables from a configmap or secret with the
To configure credentials you need to add a volume (see section Volumes) and set these environment variables.
For more information about credentials, see the
To disable or configure authentication for the console, please read the
To fine tune memory refer to the
Set environment variables for the Frank!Framework
Set the transaction manager, this is needed for transactionality support
Set the JAVA_OPTS for the Frank!Framework
Set environment variables from configmaps or secrets
To deploy the Frank!Framework, it can be needed to add some files to the container.

The Frank!Framework chart allows you to generate configmaps and secrets from values.
This is useful if you want to add local users or resources to the Frank!Framework.

Be sure to set a subPath and a mountPath if you want to avoid conflicts and use multiple secrets.
With one secret, the subPath and mountPath are not needed. And it would be possible to implement items, like this:

props.code:
generateSecret:
  - name: frankframework-resources
    mountPath: "/opt/frank/resources/"
    items:
      - key: resources.yml
        path: resources.yml
    stringData:
      resources.yml: |-
        jdbc:
          - name: frank2example
            type: org.h2.jdbcx.JdbcDataSource
            url: jdbc:h2:mem:frank2example;NON_KEYWORDS=VALUE;DB_CLOSE_ON_EXIT=FALSE;DB_CLOSE_DELAY=-1;TRACE_LEVEL_FILE=0;

children.value: The following example will generate a credentials.properties file in the /opt/frank/secrets/ folder.

props.code:
generateSecret:
 - name: frankframework-credentials
   mountPath: /opt/frank/secrets/
   stringData:
     credentials.properties: |-
       alias/uasername=C3PO
       alias/password=R2D2

children.value: There are some more examples in the
Path of the item to mount (appends mountPath)
Path where the configmap will be mounted (default /opt/frank/resources)
Path of the item to mount (appends mountPath)
Path where the secret will be mounted (default /opt/frank/secrets)
Key of the item to mount

The Frank!Framework chart allows you to create and mount volumes to the Frank!Framework.
This is useful if you want to add existing local users or resources to the Frank!Framework.
You might also use it to mount a volume containing the Configurations for the Frank!Framework.
Or to add a mount as part of the integration.
Optionally specify extra list of additional volumes for WordPress pods
Optionally specify extra list of additional volumeMounts for WordPress container(s)

The Frank!Framework chart allows you to add additional sidecar containers to the Frank!Framework pod.
This is useful if you want to add additional tools to the Frank!Framework. Like for logging.
Add additional sidecar containers to the Frank!Framework pod
Add additional init containers to the Frank!Framework pod

The console is a web application that allows you to manage the Frank!Framework.
Each Frank!Framework instance contains a build-in console, which can be accessed by going to the instance's URL and appending

.
Enabling this additional console (apart from the build-in one) will allow you to manage multiple instances of Frank!Framework from a single console.
The additional console is disabled by default, but can be enabled by setting

.
Configuring the console is done by setting the

parameters. Which can be found in the frank-console chart.
ref:
The Ladybug Database is a PostgreSQL dependency that is used to store Ladybug reports and is not needed when the Ladybug is disabled.
Note that this dependency is not used for the Frank!Framework itself, that datasource should be configured with the
The dependency is enabled by default, but can be disabled if you want to use an external or persistent database for Ladybug.
Some of the parameters are pre-configured for an easy installation, but can be changed if needed.
Override the image repository of the Ladybug Database dependency
Override the image tag of the Ladybug Database dependency
Enable the generation of secrets for the PostgreSQL dependency
Name of the secret (both for the generated secret or existing secret)

The startup probe will enable blue-green deployment, which are great for uptime during upgrades and such.
It (and the liveness probe) will check if the console is accessible, until a better health endpoint is available.
The readiness probe will check if all adapters are running using the server health endpoint
Number of Frank!Framework replicas to deploy
NOTE: ReadWriteMany PVC(s) are required if replicaCount > 1
Set the resources for the Frank!Framework containers
The resources limits for the Frank!Framework containers
The memory limit for the Frank!Framework containers
The cpu limit for the Frank!Framework containers
The requested resources for the Frank!Framework containers
The requested memory for the Frank!Framework containers
The requested cpu for the Frank!Framework containers
Number of seconds after which pods are forcefully killed
Note: Lower values may cause running adapters to fail
NOTE: podAffinityPreset, podAntiAffinityPreset, and nodeAffinityPreset will be ignored when it's set
used for database connection and log timestamps
Additional annotations for the Frank!Framework service
Enable ingress record generation for Frank!
IngressClass that will be used to implement the Ingress (Kubernetes 1.18+)
This is supported in Kubernetes 1.18+ and required if you have more than one IngressClass marked as the default for your cluster .
Additional annotations for the Ingress resource. To enable certificate autogeneration, place here your cert-manager annotations.
For a full list of possible ingress annotations, please see
Use this parameter to set the required annotations for cert-manager, see
Enable creation of ServiceAccount for Frank!Framework pod
Additional custom annotations for the ServiceAccount
The name of the ServiceAccount to use.
Changed the default database for Ladybug to PostgreSQL. This changes the auth a bit. Make sure it is configured correctly.

will determine if authentication is enabled or not. It is possible to override this with environment variables.
Read mote in the
The Frank!Framework is an ever evolving project, and as such, the chart has been updated to reflect the latest changes.
To make the chart easier to maintain, the following features have been removed:
has been removed. Configure the memory with environment variables.
has been removed. Configure the authentication with additional files and environment variables.
has been removed. Configure the credentials with volumes and environment variables.
has been removed. Configure the certificates with volumes and environment variables.
To accommodate for the removal of the above features, the following changes have been made:
has been added to allow for the generation of configmaps.
has been added to allow for the generation of secrets.
has been added to allow for the mounting of additional volumes.
has been added to allow for the mounting of additional volumes.
have been added to allow for the mounting of additional sidecars and init containers.

All these changes make the deployment much more flexible and easier to maintain.
It also doesn't require extra documentation or knowledge to use, because the deployment is the same as traditional deployments.
The common chart and its templates have been removed. Making this the main chart for other Frank!Framework-based charts.

and have a different structure.
It generates a
for the Frank!Framework. This is to allow for more flexibility.
A new chart has been added, called

. This is a web application that allows you to manage multiple instances of Frank!Framework from a single console.
It is disabled by default, but can be enabled by setting
All probes have been added to the values, making it possible to configure then separately. This could be useful if you want to make use of the new health endpoints.
The name of the chart has been renamed (frankframework) to match the project, organisation and Docker image.
notation has been changed. It is now possible to define a minimum and a maximum, and to set percentages.
is now required and should be set to the right stage. Read more in the
will default to the release namespace deployed in.

nameOverride.description: String to partially override fullname template (will maintain the release name)

fullnameOverride.description: String to fully override fullname template

tag.description: Frank!Framework image tag (immutable tags are recommended) update this tag manually to upgrade the Frank!Framework version

side.description: Set the `DTAP` side of where the instance is running, and for sideSpecific properties

name.description: Set the name of the Frank! instance (default is the `fullname`)

names.description: Set the configurations to load. Leave empty to use the default

command.description: The command to run in the container

args.description: The arguments to pass to the command

ports.description: The ports to expose in the container

JAVA_OPTS.description: Set the JAVA_OPTS for the Frank!Framework

envFrom.description: Set environment variables from configmaps or secrets

generateConfigMap/items/path.description: Path of the item to mount (appends mountPath)

generateConfigMap/mountPath.description: Path where the configmap will be mounted (default /opt/frank/resources)

generateSecret/items/path.description: Path of the item to mount (appends mountPath)

generateSecret/mountPath.description: Path where the secret will be mounted (default /opt/frank/secrets)

generateSecret/subPath.description: Key of the item to mount

extraVolumes.description: Optionally specify extra list of additional volumes for WordPress pods

extraVolumeMounts.description: Optionally specify extra list of additional volumeMounts for WordPress container(s)

sidecars.description: Add additional sidecar containers to the Frank!Framework pod

initContainers.description: Add additional init containers to the Frank!Framework pod

repository.description: Override the image repository of the Ladybug Database dependency

tag.description: Override the image tag of the Ladybug Database dependency

generatePostgresqlSecret.description: Enable the generation of secrets for the PostgreSQL dependency

secretName.description: Name of the secret (both for the generated secret or existing secret)

postgresPassword.description: Password for the PostgreSQL dependency *(no default; must be set securely)*

replicaCount.description: Number of Frank!Framework replicas to deploy

memory.description: The memory limit for the Frank!Framework containers

cpu.description: The cpu limit for the Frank!Framework containers

memory.description: The requested memory for the Frank!Framework containers

cpu.description: The requested cpu for the Frank!Framework containers

terminationGracePeriodSeconds.description: Number of seconds after which pods are forcefully killed

timeZone.description: used for database connection and log timestamps

annotations.description: Additional annotations for the Frank!Framework service

enabled.description: Enable ingress record generation for Frank!

className.description: IngressClass that will be used to implement the Ingress (Kubernetes 1.18+)

annotations.description: Additional annotations for the Ingress resource. To enable certificate autogeneration, place here your cert-manager annotations.

create.description: Enable creation of ServiceAccount for Frank!Framework pod

annotations.description: Additional custom annotations for the ServiceAccount

name.description: The name of the ServiceAccount to use.
